resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
Before we embark on optimizing or refactoring the blobstore for performance, we should benchmark performance under the current implementation -- ideally using a method that is easily repeatable -- and compare that performance to that of the candidate  implementations, constructed manually.

The first step would be to pick the appropriate set of benchmarks. Basic "dd test", mentioned in EUCA-3761, would be a good place to start, but that should be complemented by a disk benchmark that more realistically represents typical types of read-heavy and write-heavy workloads.
fields.summary: Investigate read/write block performance on local NC disk

comments.body:
Bonnie++ is a candidate test: http://www.coker.com.au/bonnie++/
FIO another option: https://github.com/axboe/fio
https://www.linux.com/learn/tutorials/442451-inspecting-disk-io-performance-with-fio/

AWS's recommendations: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/benchmark_piops.html

Bonnie++ results are hard to read due to not friendly output.
This is output from fio random read of 3g of data
-----
Direct connection (loopback from host OS attached to guest OS via virsh):

Base on that test direct connection for random reads is way faster.
[~zhill], [~dmitrii], do you think any extra tests are needed?

[~vasya], please also run a test on a direct LVM volume and a direct disk. You can attach both to a VM directly without a loopback required. I want to understand the overhead of a loopback device as well as the CoW mechanism the blobstore uses.

[~zhill] and [~dmitrii], after running fio tests for a while I can say that they are not predictable. I see 10x difference from run to run without changing any configuration. I started to run tests few times, so I'd ignore previous results. I am re-running all scenarios.
Those are best results for LVM volume
----

[~zhill], I don't know if we can trust those measurements. I can't explain why from run to run speed could have 2x difference. I also see way faster speed and low CPU utilization if file instead of block is attached. I am not sure why.
The EUCA-12067 created to track possible improvement implementation.
